article.title: Efficient Network Measurements through Approximated Windows

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the shaded region representing "τ-slack" in the figure indicate?
choices: The algorithm is allowed to completely discard data from this region.
This region represents data that is older than the required window size and will always be ignored.
The algorithm can dynamically choose whether or not to include data from this region in its calculations.
This region contains data that must always be included in the sum calculation.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE according to the data in Table 1?
choices: Exact Summing over an exact window always requires more space than a multiplicative approximation over a slack window.
For constant τ, our additive error algorithm provides the most space-efficient solution for the Basic-Summing problem.
Datar et al.’s algorithm achieves constant update time for multiplicative approximation of Basic-Summing over a slack window.
Our contributions primarily focus on improving time complexity for Basic-Summing algorithms.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following best describes the purpose of the second rounding step in the two-stage rounding technique illustrated in Figure 3?
choices: To minimize the overall additive error introduced by the rounding process.
To reduce the space required to store the sum of each block before storing it in the cyclic array.
To ensure that the final sum calculation is always an integer value.
To correct for the rounding error introduced in the first rounding step.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the primary advantage of using two summing solutions as depicted in Figure 4 for calculating standard deviation over a sliding window?
choices: It reduces the overall processing time required to calculate the standard deviation.
It allows for a more accurate estimation of the standard deviation compared to using a single summing solution.
It simplifies the calculation of the mean, which is a necessary component of the standard deviation formula.
It eliminates the need for storing the entire window of data, thereby reducing memory consumption.
